title: Digital Circuits and Computing Systems
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG2020.
description: This course gives a comprehensive insight into the principles and design of modern digital computing systems. The course content covers elementary logic gates, combinational logic circuits, arithmetic blocks, sequential circuits, and finite state machines. The topics are taught in a way to illustrate how these component blocks can be used to design a basic computer processor. A hardware description language, namely VHDL or Verilog, will be introduced for digital systems design. The course helps lay the foundation for learning the design of complex digital systems. Students will learn design methodologies and use computer-aided tools to design small and medium size digital circuits. This course includes mandatory laboratory modules, which covers the issues of health, safety and the environment.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to 1. explain the operation of basic components of a digital circuit; 2. explain how digital computers operate at the most basic level; 3. carry out experiments on assembling and testing basic digital circuits; 4. describe the architecture of a basic computer processor; 5. design medium-complexity digital systems; 6. interpret the description of a digital system using high-level languages 7.describe some common healthy and safety problems in an EE laboratory and observe laboratory safety rules
syllabus: Principles and design of modern digital computing systems; Components of digital systems: elementary logic gates, combinational logic circuits, arithmetic blocks, sequential circuits, and finite state machines; Design of basic computer processor; Hardware description language (VHDL or Verilog); Design methodologies; Small and medium-size digital circuit design.

title: Fundamentals of Electric Circuits
requirements: Not for students who have taken BMEG2300.
description: This is an introductory course on electric circuits. The main content include basic circuit laws and theorems, methods of circuit analysis, operational amplifier circuits, and the concept of linear feedback system. The basic concepts of AC circuits, including impedance, phasors, sinusoids and frequency response, will be taught. The course will also cover the fundamentals of electrical power systems, including transient analysis, three-phase circuits, inductors and transformers, and basic electromechanical principles. This course includes mandatory laboratory modules.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to: 1. state the key terminologies and fundamental concepts of electric circuit analysis and design; 2. apply circuit laws to analyze a linear circuit; 3. apply calculus and linear algebra methods to circuit analysis 4. simplify circuits for analysis by circuit theorems and transforms 5. apply complex numbers and Laplace transform in AC circuit analysis 6. carry out circuit experiments independently and appreciate the importance of applying theories to the real world through experiments 7. analyze common three-phase circuits used for electricity transmission and distribution 8. use electrical models to solve magnetic and rotary mechanical problems 9. describe how a power system functions
syllabus: Basic circuit laws and theorems; Method of circuit analysis; Operational amplifier circuits; Concept of linear feedback system; Basic concepts of AC circuits – impedance, phasors, sinusoids and frequency response; Fundamentals of electrical power systems; Transient analysis; Three-phase circuits, inductors and transformers; basic electromechanical principles.
recommended_readings: Textbooks 1. Alexander and Sadiku, Fundamentals of Electric Circuits, 6th Edition, McGraw Hill, 2016 2. Fitzgerald and Kingsley, Electric Machinery, 7th Edition, McGraw-Hill  References 1. Nilsson and Riedel, Electric Circuits, 10th edition, Pearson, 2014 2. Duncan Glover, et al, Power System – Analysis & Design, 6th edition, CL Engineering 3. Tront, PSPICE for Basic Circuit Analysis, McGraw-Hill, 2005

title: Principles of Communication Systems
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR2300 or ENGG2310 or IERG2310
description: This is a foundation course on telecommunication and related technologies. It describes the essential elements of a modern communication system. Students will learn the basic concepts in electrical communication, the operation principles and the performance requirements for a real-world communication system. The course content include signal representation and properties, amplitude modulation, angle modulation, analogue-to-digital signal conversion, demodulation and detection, pulse modulation, multiplexing, baseband transmission, passband transmission, inter-symbol interference, system performance evaluation and other topics. The course is the basis of various advanced courses on electrical and optical communications.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to: 1. describe the architecture of a communication system and explain the functions of each system component 2. describe how the signal is generated, demodulated and detected in a communication system 3. describe how noise, interference and channel distortion affect communication 4. describe the major analog modulation techniques and state their advantages and limitations 5. state the basic principles of digital transmission and describe different pulse modulation schemes 6. carry out basic system performance evaluation of a communication system
syllabus: Overview on Communication Systems; Review of Fourier Transform; Concepts of Power, Spectrum and Bandwidth; Amplitude Modulation; Angle Modulation; Generation and Detection; Digital Representation of Analog Signals; Pulse Modulation; Multiplexing; Pulse Shaping and Inter-Symbol Interference (ISI), Digital Baseband Transmission; Digital Passband Transmission; Examples of Communication Systems.

title: Introduction to Embedded Systems
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3701; Prerequisite: ELEG2201 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course introduces the basic concepts and design principles of embedded systems and teaches software-hardware co-development of a typical microcontroller-based system. Students will learn the concepts of input/output, interrupts, timer/counter, interfacing, step motors, through both classroom lectures and hands-on experiments. In the course project, students are required to propose, design and implement a complete embedded system.

title: Technology, Society and Engineering Practice
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG2601.
description: This course aims to provide electronic engineering students with an understanding about the significance and contribution of engineering and technology to the society and the professional role of engineers in the society. The topics to be covered include, but not limited to, Engineering, Innovation, Social and Economic Development; Role of Engineering in Society; Engineering Problems, Challenges and Opportunities; Project Management, Environment, Energy, Standards and Regulatory Issues; Engineering Ethics, Good Engineers and Engineer Leaders; Entrepreneurship, Business, IP and Enterprise Management; and Economic Development in China. The primary objective of this course is to imbue engineering students with a sense of social responsibility and pride in practicing engineering profession to the betterment of mankind.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to: 1. examine the impact of technology on the society and the environment. 2. recognize the contributions of engineers to the society 3. appreciate the design and innovation aspects of engineering profession 4. acquire the skills and tools to manage engineering projects 5. learn the skills for working in a team 6. understand and state the value of being an ethical engineer and a responsible citizen
syllabus: Engineering, Innovation, Social and Economic Development; Role of Engineering in Society; Engineering Problems, Challenges and Opportunities; Project Management, Environment, Energy, Standards and Regulatory Issues; Engineering Ethics, Good Engineers and Engineer Leaders; Entrepreneurship, Business, IP and Enterprise Management; and Economic Development in China.

title: Engineering Practicum
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG2602.
description: This is a practicum course that provides fundamental hands-on training on practical skills for electronic engineering students. It covers basic hardware design and implementation, use of software tools, and computer systems.

title: Introduction to Electronic System Design
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG1100 or ESTR1000
description: This is an introductory project-based course through which students learn how to design and realize a complete electronic system. Students are required to build a workable hardware system according to given specifications. The system components include electrical power supply, analog and digital circuits, sensors, actuators, display and microcontroller devices. Students will work in small groups to understand system requirements and specifications, identify design constraints, define project milestones, prototype the system and test the system. During the process of system implementation, students will acquire practical skills of software-hardware integrated design and debugging.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to 1. Design a complete electronic system to meet given requirements 2. Assemble an electronic system with properly chosen components 3. Develop embedded software in an integrated electronic system 4. Identify and solve hardware and software problems in an electronic system 5. Evaluate the performance of an electronic system 6. Work in a team and communicate effectively with teammates
syllabus: Analog circuits; digital circuits; sensors; actuators; microcontrollers; finite-state machine; hardware assembling; integrated software-hardware design; debugging methods; testing of electronic systems; safety and reliability.
recommended_readings: 1. Engineering Design: A Project-Based Introduction by Clive L. Dym and Patrick Little, John Wiley & Sons, 2009. 2. Fundamentals of Electronic Systems Design by Jens Lienig and Hans Bruemmer, Springer, 2019.

title: Medical Instrumentation and Sensors
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3240 or BMEG3101 or ESTR3210.
description: In view of the prevalence of the aging population and accompanying chronic illnesses, demands for medical instrumentation and design have been escalating worldwide. This course aims at enabling students to master design-thinking skills and by applying it to the broad medical fields. Laboratory sessions will be arranged to train students in developing prototypes and enrich their understanding of the fundamental design concepts covered in lectures.

title: Robotic Perception and Intelligence
requirements: Not for students who have taken MAEG3060 or ESTR3408 or ESTR3216; Prerequisite: ENGG2030 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course is an introduction to robotics, perception, and artificial intelligence, with concentration on robotic systems empowered with perception and intelligence for real-world applications. We start with the fundamentals of robotics and artificial intelligence. The technical topics include electronic and mechanical components of robots, sensors and robotic vision, sensor data fusion and evaluation, signal and image processing. The knowledge areas cover robotics, machine learning and artificial intelligence, robot motion and task planning, robotic programming, and human-robot interaction. It aims to help students establish a wide-spectrum understanding about the principles and the fundamental knowledge of robotics, perception and intelligence in a real-world context.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1) Explain the basic components and movements of robots; 2) Explain the dynamics and control of robot systems 3) Explain the use of sensors in robotic perception and vision 4) Explain the principles and design of robot intelligence 5) Describe the technology trend of intelligent robots 6) Describe successful applications of intelligent robots in solving real-world problems

title: Microelectronic Devices and Circuits
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3200; Prerequisite: ELEG2202 or BMEG2300 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course provides the basic knowledge of semiconductor physics, including electrons and holes, energy band diagram, Fermi energy, intrinsic and doped semiconductors, drift and diffusion currents. The principles of P-N junctions, bipolar and MOS transistors will be explained. The device performance measures, namely current efficiency, transit frequency and intrinsic gain, will be introduced. Other topics covered include frequency response of transistor amplifiers, filters, feedback, stability, frequency compensation, and oscillators. This course includes mandatory laboratory modules.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to: 1. explain the operating principles of major semiconductor devices, namely, p-n junction diode, BJT transistor and MOS transistor 2. evaluate the performance of a semiconductor device 3. analyze a transistor circuit across different frequency ranges 4. design a simple transistor circuit to meet given specifications 5. explain the principle of feedback and the properties of different feedback topologies 6. apply feedback in circuit design and perform stability analysis of a feedback circuit 7. design simple oscillators 8. carry out experiments on microelectronic circuits independently and analyze the experimental results
syllabus: Semiconductor physics; Electrons and holes; Energy band diagram; Fermi Energy; Intrinsic and doped semiconductors; Drift and diffusion currents; Principles of P-N junctions; Bipolar and MOS transistors; Device performance measures: current efficiency, transit frequency, intrinsic gain; Frequency response of transistor amplifiers; Filters; Feedback; Stability; Frequency compensation; Oscillators.
recommended_readings: Textbooks  1. Jaeger and Blalock, Microelectronic Circuit Design, 3rd Edition, McGraw Hill, 2007. 2. Sedra and Smith, Microelectronic Circuits (Oxford Series in Electrical & Computer Engineering), 5th Edition, Oxford, 2004.  References  1. Streetman and Banerjee, Solid-State Electronic Devices, 7th edition, Pearson, 2015 2. Fonstad, Microelectronic Devices and Circuits, 2006 Electronic Edition.

title: Analog Integrated Circuits
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3210.;Prerequisite: ELEG2202 or BMEG2300 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course teaches analog integrated circuits with focuses on three circuits: operational amplifier (opamp), bandgap voltage reference and linear regulator. The performance metrics of these circuits are introduced, and the analysis and design of these circuits at the transistor level are taught. Stability and frequency compensation of opamps with feedback are analyzed. Noise analysis is introduced. The course also covers data converters and filters.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to - develop an overall picture of analog IC design - understand design considerations and tradeoffs for analog IC - Perform analog circuit design using CAD tool
syllabus: Non-ideal opamp; Transistor amplifier design; Opamp design; Feedback analysis; Stability and frequency compensation; Noise analysis; Current source; Bandgap voltage reference; Linear regulator; Data converter; Filter.
recommended_readings: Reference Book: B. Razavi, Design of Analog CMOS Integrated Circuits. Boston, MA: McGraw-Hill, 2001

title: Electromagnetic Fields and Waves
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3213 or ESTR3214.
description: This course is designed to prepare electronic engineering students with the foundation knowledge for learning radio and optical communication technologies. It starts with the review of vector differential operators. The course content cover time-varying fields, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic wave propagation, reflection and transmission, transmission line theory, Smith Chart, microwave and optical waveguides, transients on transmission lines, antenna radiation, and basic concepts of wireless and optical communications. This course includes mandatory laboratory modules.

title: Wireless Technology and Systems
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3214 or ESTR3202.
description: This course is designed for electronic engineering students to learn how to design basic antennas for wireless terminals and to understand the wireless systems from radio propagation perspectives. It starts with the review of Maxwell's equations and their solutions for far fields. The course discusses the basic concepts for various electrical small and resonant type antennas, antenna array and teacheshow to design practical antennas for wireless terminals. The basic characteristics of radio propagation are studied for a better understanding of modern wireless communication systems, for examples, satellite communications and mobile technology. This course includes mandatory laboratory modules.

title: Modern Digital Circuit Design
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4216.
description: This course teaches the design methods for modern digital circuits. Digital circuit technology trends are described. Implementation methods and design flows for modern digital circuits are explained in detail, and their trade-offs are discussed. Advanced circuit techniques in digital designs are introduced. Design tools, e.g., Verilog, are taught. Packaging and testing of digital integrated circuits are briefed.

title: Introduction to Power Electronics
requirements: Pre-requisite: ELEG2202 or BMEG2300 or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This is an introductory course to power electronics. Semiconductor power switches and the principles and methods of switched-mode power conversion are introduced first. Important concepts needed in power electronics are reviewed. The course then goes to analyze and design four categories of switched-mode power converters: AC-DC, DC-DC, DC-AC and AC-AC, their different modes of operations, and their applications, for instance, in DC power supplies, electric vehicle chargers and clean energy generation systems. Control circuits employing negative feedback for switched-mode DC-DC converters are introduced and analyzed, and their design methods are illustrated.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students will be able to: 1. describe the characteristics of common semiconductor power devices. 2. analyze a power converter circuit of any type: AC-DC, DC-DC, DC-AC, AC-AC. 3. design a power converter circuit of any type to meet a given set of specifications. 4. design a stable control circuit for a DC-DC converter. 5. apply a Spice software to simulate a power converter circuit. 6. conduct power electronic experiments and interpret experimental data.
syllabus: Single-phase and three-phase electrical systems; principles and methods of electric power conversion; semiconductor power switches; rectifiers with different loads; power factor correction circuits; DC-to-DC converters of different topologies in continuous-current and discontinuous-current modes; controls and electrical isolations; switch-mode DC power supplies; DC-to-AC inverters; power electronics in clean energy generation systems.
recommended_readings: 1. Power Electronics, D.W.Hart, McGRAW-HILL 2011 2. Power Electronics – Converters, Applications, and Design, 3rd Edition, by Mohan, Undeland and Robbins, Wiley, 2006

title: Fundamentals of Applied Electromagnetics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3203 or ESTR3214.
description: This course is designed to prepare electronic engineering students with the foundation knowledge for learning radio and optical communication technologies. It starts with the review of vector differential operators. The course content cover time-varying fields, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic wave propagation, reflection and transmission, transmission line theory, Smith Chart, microwave and optical waveguides, transients on transmission lines, antenna radiation, and basic concepts of wireless and optical communications. This course includes mandatory laboratory modules.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to: 1. apply mathematical methods to explain and analyze electromagnetic field and wave propagation problems; 2. explain the working principles of common microwave and optical transmission lines and devices; 3. design a simple antenna and a matching network, and conduct relevant measurement using a vector network analyzer; 4. describe key practical issues and technical challenges in radio and optical communication systems.
syllabus: Review of vector calculous; Maxwell’s equations; Complex power conservation; Boundary conditions and uniqueness theorem; Scalar and vector potential functions; Fundamentals of electromagnetic wave radiation and antennas; Plane wave solution, wave reflection and refraction; Transmission line theory and impedance matching; Smith Chart; Microwave waveguides and resonators in wireless communication systems; Optical waveguides and devices in communication systems.

title: Antennas and Wave Propagation for Wireless Communications
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3204 or ESTR3202.;Pre-requisite: ELEG3213 or consent of the instructor.
description: This course is designed for electronic engineering students to learn how to design basic antennas for wireless terminals and to understand the wireless systems from radio propagation perspectives. It starts with the review of Maxwell’s equations and their solutions for far fields. The course discusses the basic concepts for various electrical small and resonant type antennas, antenna array and teaches how to design practical antennas for wireless terminals. The basic characteristics of radio propagation are studied for a better understanding of modern wireless communication systems, for examples, satellite communications and mobile technology. This course includes mandatory laboratory modules.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to 1. give mathematical description of antennas and radio propagation; 2. design practical antennas for wireless terminals using industry-standard EDA software; 3. explain the basic concepts of antenna arrays; 4. explain the basic concepts of radio propagation; 5. calculate a system link budget for a given radio channel and a communication system; 6. describe the architecture of a satellite communication system.
syllabus: Review of Maxwell’s equations; Basic concepts of electrical small and resonant type antennas; Practical antennas for wireless terminals; Basic concept of antenna arrays; Basic concept of antenna characterization; Radio wave propagation phenomena; Multi-path fading; Path loss, link budget and fade margin; Basic principles of mobile communications; Basic principles of satellite communications.

title: Principles of Semiconductor Devices
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG2510 or ESTR3204.
description: The course teaches the physical principles behind semiconductor devices. It starts by reviewing the particle-wave properties of electrons and photons. The problems of electrons in a 1-D potential well and electron scattering in potential barriers are addressed. Fundamental concept and theories of semiconductor devices are introduced: hydrogen atoms, bonds, crystal structures, band theory of solids, effective mass, and the Fermi energy. Electric conductions in semiconductors are taught: intrinsic and extrinsic, drift, mobility, diffusion, recombination, Hall effect. Properties and structures of metal-semiconductor junction, p-n junction and MOS capacitor are analyzed, and their breakdown effects are described. Semiconductor transistors, including MOSFET and JFET, are briefly introduced. Integrated circuits fabrication is also described: layer formation, photolithography and layout.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to - gain the basic knowledge and skills in preliminarily understanding semiconductors and device operation, and note the scope and limitation of microelectronics. - apply the learned knowledge and skills in semiconductors for analysis of various device operation modes and basic functionalities, semiconductor measurement techniques, and semiconductor device fabrication. - understand the technological impact of microelectronics on society. - understand the basic physical principles and the engineering know-how of semiconductor devices for further specialization in areas related to solid-state electronics and IC design.
syllabus: Review of electron and photon properties; Electrons in the 1-D potential well and potential barrier; Fundamentals: hydrogen atoms, bonds, crystal structures, the concept of band theory of solids, effective mass, and the Fermi energy; Conduction in semiconductors: intrinsic extrinsic, drift, mobility, diffusion, recombination, Hall effect; Junctions: metal/semiconductor, p/n, breakdown, MOS capacitor; Introduction to transistors: MOSFET, JFET; Introduction to IC fabrication: layer formation, photolithography, layout.
recommended_readings: Text: B. G. Streetman, Solid State Electronic Devices, 6th Ed., Prentice- Hall, 2006 Reference book:R. F. Pierret, Semiconductor Device Fundamentals, Addison Wesley, 1996S. M. Sze, Semiconductor Devices – Physics and Technology (1st Edition), John Wiley & Sons, 1985 Internet resources: Web book [http://ece-www.colorado.edu/~bart/book/]History of transistors [http://semiconductormuseum.com/]

title: Fundamentals of Photonics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3010.
description: This course covers the fundamental knowledge in photonics and its applications in engineering. The topics include review of ray optics, wave and beam optics, Fourier optics and optical image formation, holography and holographic storage, polarization optics and liquid crystal display technology, light emitting diodes, optical resonators and lasers, optical interconnects and switches, optical fiber communications and fiber sensors. The applications of photonic technology in modern consumer products will also be explained.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to - gain the fundamental knowledge and skills in photonics, and understand the advantages and limitation of the technology. - apply their knowledge and skills in optics for design in optical elements, optical measurement techniques, and optical instrumentation. - understand the technological impact of photonics to the society. - understand the basic physical principle and the engineering of photonics for further specialization in areas related to optical science and optical engineering.
syllabus: Review of ray optics, wave and beam optics, Fourier optics and optical image formation, holography and holographic storage, polarization optics and liquid crystal display technology, light emitting diodes, optical resonators and lasers, optical interconnects and switches, optical fiber communications and fiber sensors; Applications of photonic technology in modern consumer products

title: Introduction to Optical Communications
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3320 or ESTR3206.
description: This course covers the physics, technology, and engineering applications of optical communications. The topics include overview on the development of fiber communications, optical fibers and their properties, LED and Laser sources, optical power launching and coupling, optical detectors and receivers, repeaters, regenerators, and optical amplifiers, introduction to optical communication systems, modulation and multiplexing technologies, optical networks, and nonlinear fiber optics. Recent developments in optical communication technology will also be discussed.

title: Introduction to Digital Signal Processing
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3410.;Prerequisite: ENGG2030 or ESTR2206 or consent of the instructor.
description: This course teaches the principles and methods of digital signal processing. The course content covers discrete-time Fourier transform (DTFT), discrete Fourier transform (DFT), z-transform, linear-time invariant (LTI) system, impulse response, frequency response, transfer function, stability and causality, properties of digital filters, digital filter design and realization. This course provides the foundation for learning advanced signal processing topics.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to - apply Fourier transforms to analyze frequency-domain properties of discrete-time periodic and aperiodic signals - analyze the properties of discrete-time linear time-invariant systems - analyze magnitude and phase responses of a digital filter - determine the stability and causality of a system - describe and explain the major techniques of IIR and FIR filter design - apply filter design tools to design digital filters according to given specifications - state the considerations on filter implementation
syllabus: Discrete-time Fourier transform (DTFT), discrete Fourier transform (DFT), z-transform, linear-time invariant (LTI) system, impulse response, frequency response, transfer function, stability and causality, properties of digital filters, digital filter design and realization.

title: Introduction to Electric Power Systems
requirements: Pre-requisite: (ELEG2202 or BMEG2300) and (ENGG1310 or ENGG2520 or ESTR1003), or with consent of the instructor.
description: This is an introductory course on electric power systems and electrical to mechanical energy conversion. Electric power systems have become increasingly important as a way of transmitting and transforming energy in industrial, military and transportation uses. They are also at the heart of alternative energy systems, including wind and solar electric, geothermal and small-scale hydroelectric generation. This course covers fundamentals of energy-handling electric circuits, power electronic circuits such as inverters, and electromechanical apparatus; modeling of magnetic field devices and description of their behavior using appropriate models; analysis of power electric circuits, magnetic circuits, and elements of linear and rotating electric machinery; models of synchronous, induction, and DC machinery; the interconnection of electric power apparatus and operation of power systems.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will: -         acquire a basic understanding of the historical development and fundamental concepts of electric power systems; -         understand how the power systems work and the related power generation, conversion, distribution, and applications; and -         develop independent capability of designing and analysing simple electric power systems, especially in connection to the alternative energy systems.
syllabus: This is an introductory course on electric power systems and electrical to mechanical energy conversion. Electric power systems have become increasingly important as a way of transmitting and transforming energy in industrial, military and transportation uses. They are also at the heart of alternative energy systems, including wind and solar electric, geothermal and small-scale hydroelectric generation. This course covers fundamentals of energy-handling electric circuits, power electronic circuits such as inverters, and electromechanical apparatus; modeling of magnetic field devices and description of their behavior using appropriate models; analysis of power electric circuits, magnetic circuits, and elements of linear and rotating electric machinery; models of synchronous, induction, and DC machinery; the interconnection of electric power apparatus and operation of power systems.

title: Electronic Product Design and Development
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3710.
description: This course aims to provide basic training and hands-on experience on electronic product design and development. Topics to be learnt include information search; project planning; design methodology; selection of components; prototyping; testing procedures; trouble shooting; and documentation. The course will consist of lectures (basic training) and laboratory practice relating to the development of electronic products with pre-defined specifications.

title: Embedded Systems Design
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG2401 or IERG3060 or IERG3810; Pre-requisite: (ELEG2201 and ELEG2202)or with the consent of the instructor.
description: This course introduces the basic concepts and design principles of embedded systems and teaches software-hardware co-development of a typical microcontroller-based system. Students will learn the concepts of input/output, interrupts, timer/counter, interfacing, step motors, through both classroom lectures and hands-on experiments. In the course project, students are required to propose, design and implement a complete embedded system.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to 1. explain the roles of hardware and software in an embedded computing system; 2. explain the architecture of a modern micro-controller unit; 3. perform computer programming to control the operation of a micro-controller unit; 4. perform experiments on microcontroller hardware and software; 5. design and implement an embedded system using micro-controller unit.
syllabus: Architecture and operating principles of microcontroller; Microcontroller programming; Integrated development environment (IDE); Input/output; Interrupts; Timer and counter; Interfacing and step motor; Project design; System implementation.
recommended_readings: Textbooks: Ajay V Deshmukh, Microcontrollers – Theory and Applications, McGraw-Hill, 2005

title: Integrated Design of Mobile Applications with Sensors and Actuators
requirements:
Not for students who have taken CSCI3310.
Prerequisite: ELEG2700 or ENGG1100 or ESTR1000 or consent of the instructor.
description: This course aims at teaching students to develop integrated applications on mobile devices with external sensors and actuators. It begins with an introduction to the basic concepts and hands-on training on mobile application programming, followed by user interface design for heterogeneous mobile platforms, and the integration of widgets, classes, cloud storage, networking, messaging, etc. Advanced multimedia features, including animation and augmented reality, and essential security issues are also covered. title: CMOS Integrated Circuits
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4211 or ELEG4260.
description: This course reviews the transistor and wire characteristics and models in modern digital CMOS technologies. Performance metrics for digital circuits are introduced. Design and optimization of various types of digital integrated circuits are discussed. They include static combinational logic circuits, dynamic combinational logic circuits, and sequential logic circuits. An exemplary arithmetic circuit is studied. The course also covers the design of memory and array structures, noise in digital systems, I/O and signaling conventions.

title: Radio Frequency Electronics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4213 or ELEG4214 or ESTR4206 or ESTR4220.
description: This course gives an overall picture of the design and implementation of RF circuits which provides the understanding of the basic microwave theories and concepts (e.g. transmission line, microstrip, Smith chart, impedance matching, microwave network analysis, scattering-parameters and measurement technique); the operating principles of RF devices and circuits (e.g. power divider, RF switch, etc); as well as hands-on experience in RF circuit realization (e.g. simulation, fabrication, characterization).

title: Power Converter Circuits
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4215.;Prerequisite: ELEG3202 or consent of the instructor.
description: This course introduces power converter circuits and their operating principles. The types of power converters covered include voltage reference circuits, shunt and series linear regulators, charge pump circuits and switched-mode dc-dc converters.

title: RF Circuits for Wireless Systems
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4203 or ELEG4204 or ELEG4213 or ESTR4206 or ESTR4208 or ESTR4220 or ESTR4222.;Pre-requisite: ELEG3203 or ELEG3213 or ESTR3214 or consent of the instructor.
description: This course is for electronic engineering students to lay the essential foundation for learning the design of radio frequency circuits. It provides the system perspectives of wireless communication. The course starts with the review of transmission line theory and covers basic passive and active RF circuits, including impedance matching circuits, couplers, power divider, filters, amplifiers, etc. The basic concepts of wireless system design are discussed. This course includes mandatory laboratory modules.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to 1. apply mathematical techniques to analyze basic RF circuits. 2. design practical RF passive circuits using industry standard EDA software 3. explain the basic design principles and key parameters of RF active circuits. 4. describe the architecture and key system parameters of a wireless communication system
syllabus: Review of transmission lines; Microstrip lines; Impedance matching; Microwave network theory; Scattering parameters, Microwave CAD tools, Microwave measurement techniques; Microwave passive circuits (e.g. couplers, power divider), Microwave active circuits (e.g. RF switch, amplifiers); RF system parameters and analysis.

title: Power Converter Circuits
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4205.;Prerequisite: ELEG3202 or consent of the instructor.

title: Design Methodology of Modern Digital Circuits
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG3205.
description: This course teaches the design methods for modern digital circuits. Digital circuit technology trends are described. Implementation methods and design flows for modern digital circuits are explained in detail, and their trade-offs are discussed. Advanced circuit techniques in digital designs are introduced. Design tools, e.g., Verilog, are taught. Packaging and testing of digital integrated circuits are briefed.

title: Physics and Technology of Semiconductor Devices
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4311 or ELEG4510 or ESTR4210 or ESTR4216.
description: This course first review the fundamental knowledge about semiconductor physics and MOSFET transistors and go through various advanced silicon based devices and technologies, including NMOS, CMOS, CCD, TFT and SOI. Junction devices, namely bipolar junction transistors, tunnel diodes, heterojunction and quantum-well devices, and quantum dots, are introduced. Silicon based memory technologies, including DRAM, floating gate MOSFET, flash memory, are covered. The course also gives introduction to photonic devices, for examples, light emitting devices (LEDs), semiconductor lasers, photodetectors, and solar cells. Organic electronics, including organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) and organic thin film transistors, and flexible electronic devices are described.

title: Microoptics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELEG4312.
description: This course covers the physics of micro-optical devices and systems. Topics include optical coherence and interference, thin film optical filters, optical diffraction, principles of optical waveguides, photodetectors and optical modulators, optical imaging subsystems. It also gives an introduction to optical coherence tomography and LIDAR.

title: Intelligent Interactive Robot Practice
description: This is a project-based course that aims at offering students hands-on learning experience on the subject topics of robotics, perception and AI with applications in human-robot interaction. Students are required to first put together a workable mobile robotic manipulation platform using the provided mobile base and robotic arm, customized with perception sensing devices. Subsequently students will use the mobile robotic manipulation system and the sensing devices to achieve perception and AI empowered real-world human-robot interaction with prescribed task objectives and scopes. Students will work in small groups to study the hardware and learn the required ROS (Robot Operating System) software platform, understand the task requirements, work out feasible solutions, and accomplish the course project objectives. During the process, students will acquire basic knowledge and practical skills of robotics, perception and AI via a hands-on learning approach.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to 1. Design a complete mobile robotic system to meet given requirements 2. Assemble the designed robotic system with customizable sensing devices 3. Develop ROS based algorithm software for the assembled robotic system 4. Provide solutions with feasibility studies to the prescribed application tasks 5. Implement the solutions on the robotic system to accomplish tasks objectives 6. Learn to work in a team and communicate effectively with teammates
syllabus: Introduction to mobile and manipulation robots; Introduction to human-computer interaction; Introduction to perception and AI in robotics; Introduction to ROS and OS based robot programming; integrated hardware-software design, feasibility study and implementation; testing of robotic system; safety and reliability.
recommended_readings: 1. Introduction to Robotics: Mechanics and Control, Third Edition, by John J. Craig, Prentice-Hall (Pearson), 2005  2. Robotic, Vision and Control, by Peter Corke, Springer, 2011

title: Analog-Digital ASIC Design
requirements: For ELEG major and minor undergraduate and ELEG RPg and TPg students as elective course; Not for students who have taken ELEG5201

title: Digital Processing of Speech Signals
requirements: For students in MSc Electronic Engineering
description: This course starts with a review of digital signal processing fundamentals and a general introduction to speech communication. title: Advanced Signal Processing for Communications
requirements: For students in MSc Electronic Engineering
description: This course starts with a background review before introducing the latest signal processing techniques in modern communications. The course content includes transmission of digital baseband signals, PCM, delta modulation, ISI, pulse shaping, partial response; least square optimal and adaptive filtering, LMS and RLS algorithms, adaptive equalizer and echo canceller; bandpass data transmission, binary and M-ary ASK, FSK, PSK and DPSK. They should be able to comprehend the technical aspects of different signal formatting methods and digital modulation schemes. Through studying the bit error rate (BER) performance, students should be able to investigate how channel fading affects the performance of a digital transmission system. They should learn the effect of different multiplexing and multiple access techniques in terms of channel capacity performance and practical implementation details. Students should also be familiarized with the technologies and standards of the many wireless communication systems in use.

title: Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor Devices
requirements: For students in MSc Electronic Engineering
description: This course starts with a review of semiconductor fundamentals such as electron and hole, Fermi energy, carrier generation and recombination, p-n junction, metal-semiconductor Schottky diodes, carrier mobility, effective mass. The course content covers conventional semiconductor properties, namely electronic structures, optical and electrical properties, metal-oxide capacitors, junction fieldeffect transistors (JFET), metal-oxide-semiconductor field transistors (MOSFET), NMOS technology, basic CMOS technology, charge coupled devices and sensors, MOS transistor modeling, simulation, and design, advanced MOS transistors. Fabrication methods for MOSFETs, including sputtering, CVD, VPD, oxidation, ion implantation, etching, photolithography, metallization, silicon wafer fabrication technology, transistor on-wafer test, etc. will be introduced. The course also covers the basic principles of deep submicron devices: down-scaling benefits and rules, current issues and trends, FinFETs; memory devices; RAM and ROM; SOI technology, BiCMOS technology, thin film transistor (TFT), non-volatile memory devices, device characterization. Other topics may include neuromorphic transistors, system on chips (SoCs), electronic packaging technology, fabrication systems, reliability, life-cycle analysis, markets and policies.Students will learn not only the conventional device physics and fabrication technologies, but also the state-of-the-art device technologies.

The course also covers the basic principles of photovoltaic devices, including absorption, photo-electric conversion, conversion efficiency, loss mechanism, carrier collection, device characterization. The fourth-generation solar cell technology, e.g., monocrystalline solar cells, thin-film solar cells, dye-sensitized solar cells, organic solar cells, will be introduced. Other topics include light harvesting, management techniques, manufacturing systems, reliability, life-cycle analysis, markets and policies.

title: Innovation, Technology and Management in Modern Engineering
